wordPressPost.title: How to Start a Raw Food Diet the Right Way: Pros and Cons
wordPressPost.content:
We need clean, fresh foods full of antioxidants to feel energized. A raw food diet provides you with living nutrients without taxing your cells. A diet of at least 75% raw food offers numerous health benefits, starting with weight loss and detox. Read about all the benefits of a raw food diet and try some simple but yummy recipes.

Eating raw foods is natural. Raw foods offer the benefice of consuming uncooked and fresh foods. By eating raw or just by increasing the number of raw foods in your diet can help you reverse many health concerns that are plaguing your life; starting with stubborn fat. 

Raw food diets are based on unprocessed and uncooked plant foods, preferably organic, such as a variety of fresh fruits and veggies, nuts, seeds, grains, dried fruit, fresh juices, and purified water.

Why doing a raw food diet?

Eating raw can help to add “living food in your diet”. Living foods and juices contain the maximum amount of fiber found in raw produce, the fiber that can be lost in processing. Such foods are easily metabolized and tend to be lower in calories than the average diet.

Some studies suggest that heating food above 116°F destroys enzymes in food that aid in digestion and in the absorption of food, diminishing its nutritional value.

4 types of raw food diet

  • raw vegan;
  • raw vegetarian;
  • raw omnivores;
  • and raw carnivore. The raw carnivore does eat meat but only if it’s uncooked.

Benefits of a Raw Food Diet

A diet of at least 75% raw food offers numerous health benefits, such as:

  • increased energy,
  • improved skin appearance,
  • better digestion,
  • weight loss and reduced risk of serious illnesses like heart disease, diabetes, and cancer.

A raw food diet contains little or no saturated fats that are low in sodium, high in potassium, magnesium, folate, and fiber. Raw food diets are also excellent detox diets. You can make your own smoothies and juicing combinations upon your tastebuds and health needs. Many people use a raw food diet to detox and give their body a rest while cleansing the colon, liver or kidney, even the skin. It’s refreshing and rejuvenating when done for the short term. 

The Basics of a Raw Food Diet

The raw food list is pretty simple: fresh fruits, vegetables, grains, nuts and seeds, legumes and beans, and even seaweed. These are part of a raw food diet menu. Other staples are fermented foods, young coconut milk, and sundried fruits. Your choice of foods may depend on your reasons for dieting, for example:

  • sprouted brown rice slows glucose absorption and improves the metabolism
  • cabbage supports healthy cellular function; radish leaves act as an anti-oxidant, as does Shitake mushroom
  • carrots are a great source of vitamin A as well as encouraging healthy vision and a healthy cardiovascular system

You can use a sprouter such as the Easy Green automatic sprouter to sprout seeds, grains, beans – even wheatgrass.

Health benefits of sprouts;

Sprouts could be called a ‘superfood’ – organic sprouts contain enormous levels of:

  • proteins,
  • vitamins and minerals,
  • trace minerals,
  • chlorophyll pigments,
  • and enzymes,
  • and are the ideal natural supplement.

Sprouts can be used in salads and soups or can be juiced.

Foods that are not on the menu:

  • cooked foods,
  • refined and processed foods,
  • sugar,
  • and caffeine,
  • as well as processed oils.

Anti-inflammatory juicing recipe:

A great juicing recipe to complement a raw food diet is carrot juice with potato, fennel, and apple.

  • Simply juice 4 medium carrots,
  • 2 apples,
  • 1 small potato
  • and 1 small stalk of fennel.

Fennel has been shown to reduce and control inflammation of arthritis, it evens mood fluctuation and depressive states and has the rare nutrient called manganese, plus zinc and vitamin B complex.

The nutritional value of grains and seeds is incredible. They contain most of the vitamins – particularly A, B, and E; and unsaturated fatty acids and lecithin, as well as being an excellent source of proteins.

Dairy alternatives:

If you are menopausal then boosting your estrogen level with soy is an excellent idea. You can even use soy makers (such as SoyQuick) to make non-dairy drinks from different sources such as:

  • rice,
  • nuts and seeds,
  • and grains to have with breakfast.

If you want something a little bit thicker than soy and nut milk, that you can use in your raw deserts then use tofu. Tofu is full of health benefits; however make sure to buy organic, non- GMO soy products. I have outlined the top delicious dairy alternatives in my article: “How to Live Lactose-Free by Using Delicious Alternatives”.

Raw food prep:

Essentially, the idea of a raw food diet is to eat unprocessed foods for at least 75% of the time. If the idea of raw food isn’t very appetizing to you, you can warm the food a little as long as the food isn’t heated above 116°F. We are talking about:

  • Fruits and veggies: are juiced and used to make smoothies; you can even sundry.
  • Nuts: are soaked overnight.
  • Grains and some beans: are also soaked.

Detox reaction:

Because a raw food diet is detoxifying some people suffer a mild detox reaction including mild headaches, nausea, and cravings. These symptoms may last for several days and you’ll get more enjoyment out of your raw food diet if you cut down on things like meat, sugar, and caffeine a week or so before commencing the diet.

Prep time:

A raw food diet is certainly a good way to improve your overall health and wellbeing. Like anything worthwhile, it takes time, energy and commitment. Because many of the foods for this particular type of diet are made from scratch there is some preparation time involved. There are many great products on the market that can help you prepare your own living food and save you some time as well. The best thing to do is to subscribe to a meal prep community. 

The cons of a raw food diet:

While it can help with all those health issues mentioned above; prolonged use might be detrimental to health and causing:

  • digestive problems;
  • and toxicity; as cooking kills off bacteria and toxins. A diet consisting of raw meat, eggs, and even certain beans and grains is toxic;
  • a raw vegan might be at risk of not getting enough nutrients.

A raw food diet should be considered by overweight individuals that are facing inflammatory conditions. 

Best supplements to support the elimination process:

  • probiotics,
  • multi-vitamins,
  • greens,
  • fermented mushrooms,
  • and proteolytic digestive enzymes. Especially if you are prone to digestive issues. 

Final thought

A raw food diet is not supposed to be a cure-all; it has to be used in conjunction with regular exercise to see the maximum results. Make sure to drink adequate alkaline water to minimize the detoxing effects. Keep a journal of gratitude and do some fun things while doing a raw food diet and any diet for instance. No diet is meant to be one size fits all; find what works for you. 

Caution:

As with any major change in diet, it’s a wise idea to consult your doctor before beginning a special diet. This is especially true for children, pregnant women, anyone with anemia and anyone with a pre-existing medical condition.
